description: A region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape from it.
Vast systems of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter bound together by gravity.
Planets that orbit stars outside our solar system.
The prevailing cosmological model that explains the origin and evolution of the universe.
Giant clouds of gas and dust in space where stars are born.
Explosive events that occur at the end of a star's life, releasing immense amounts of energy.
Highly magnetized, rotating neutron stars that emit beams of electromagnetic radiation.
A form of matter that does not emit, absorb, or reflect light, but is thought to make up about 27% of the universe's mass-energy content.
The thermal radiation emitted by a perfect absorber of electromagnetic radiation.
A space telescope that has provided some of the most detailed images of distant galaxies and celestial phenomena.
Extremely luminous and energetic sources of electromagnetic radiation, powered by supermassive black holes.
Highly compact stars composed almost entirely of neutrons, formed from the remnants of supernova explosions.
A hypothetical cloud of icy objects believed to be the source of long-period comets.
Short-lived bursts of gamma-ray radiation, the brightest electromagnetic events in the universe.
An elementary particle in the Standard Model of particle physics, believed to give mass to other particles.
Three laws describing the motion of planets around the Sun, formulated by Johannes Kepler.
A relationship between the distance to galaxies and their recessional velocity, indicating the expansion of the universe.
A stream of charged particles ejected from the Sun's upper atmosphere, influencing the solar system and Earth's magnetosphere.
Our home galaxy, a spiral galaxy containing the Solar System.
A type of emission nebula formed when a star sheds its outer layers at the end of its life.
The remnant radiation from the Big Bang, providing crucial evidence for the Big Bang theory.
The technique of taking photographs of celestial objects and phenomena.
The study of the origin, evolution, distribution, and future of life in the universe.
Man-made objects in orbit around Earth that no longer serve a useful purpose.
Small, rocky objects that orbit the Sun, mostly found in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter.
Small celestial bodies composed of ice, dust, and rock that orbit the Sun in highly elliptical orbits.
discoverer: Multiple, including Chinese, Babylonian, and Greek astronomers

description: When Earth comes between the Sun and the Moon, casting a shadow on the Moon's surface.
significance: Used historically to measure celestial distances and times.

description: When the Moon passes between the Sun and Earth, blocking all or part of the Sun's light.
significance: Used to study the Sun's corona and atmosphere.

description: Telescopes placed in space to observe astronomical objects without interference from Earth's atmosphere.
A persistent high-pressure region on Jupiter, known for its swirling appearance and vibrant color.
Dense stellar remnants of low to medium mass stars, supported by electron degeneracy pressure.
Stars that exhibit periodic changes in luminosity due to pulsations in their outer layers.
Spherical collections of stars bound together by gravity, often found in the halo of galaxies.
The study of the chemical elements and compounds found in space, and their formation and interaction.
A hypothetical form of energy that is thought to be responsible for the accelerating expansion of the universe.
discoverer: Supernova Cosmology Project and High-Z Supernova Search Team

description: The application of statistics to astronomy, including data analysis, modeling, and inference.
Ripples in spacetime caused by accelerating masses, predicted by Einstein's theory of general relativity.
discoverer: LIGO Scientific Collaboration and Virgo Collaboration

description: The process by which elements are formed inside stars through nuclear reactions.
The process by which stars change over time, from formation to death, based on their mass.
The study of geology as it relates to celestial bodies, including planets, moons, and asteroids.
The application of data science and informatics to the field of astronomy, including data mining, machine learning, and visualization.
Highly luminous centers of galaxies believed to be powered by accretion onto supermassive black holes.
The study of the potential for life beyond Earth, including the search for extraterrestrial life and habitable environments.
The study of gamma-ray emissions from celestial objects, revealing extreme energy processes such as black holes and supernovae.
The study of the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation, providing insights into composition, temperature, and motion of celestial objects.
The study of the long-term changes in the climate of celestial bodies, such as planets and moons.
The study of the behavior of fluids in astrophysical environments, such as stars, galaxies, and accretion disks.
The ethical considerations and implications of space exploration, colonization, and potential contact with extraterrestrial life.
The use of astronomical techniques to investigate historical events, such as dating ancient celestial observations.
Microscopic particles of matter in space, including interstellar dust and debris from comets and asteroids.
The matter and radiation that exists in the space between the star systems in a galaxy.
Objects in the solar system that orbit the Sun beyond the orbit of Neptune, including dwarf planets like Pluto.
discoverer: David C. Jewitt and Jane X. Luu

description: The study of the physical properties and processes of celestial bodies, particularly their interactions with the Earth.
The study of the interior of the Sun by the analysis of its modes of vibration.
The precise measurement of the positions and movements of stars and other celestial bodies.
A binary star system where the orbital plane of the two stars is such that one star passes in front of the other, causing eclipses.
Dense, opaque clouds of gas and dust that block the light from background objects.
The displacement of spectral lines towards longer wavelengths in radiation from distant galaxies, indicating their motion away from us.
The measure of a planet's potential to develop and sustain life.
The study of the origin, evolution, distribution, and future of life in the universe.
The study of the nuclear reactions and processes that occur in stars and other celestial bodies.
The bending of light rays by the gravitational field of massive objects, used to study dark matter and distant galaxies.
The faint radiation left over from the Big Bang, providing a snapshot of the early universe.
The categorization of stars based on their spectral characteristics, such as temperature and luminosity.
discoverer: Edward C. Pickering and Williamina Fleming

description: The study of the history and evolution of galaxies, including their formation, structure, and interactions.
High-speed streams of matter ejected from a celestial object, often associated with black holes and young stars.
The study of the origin, evolution, and eventual fate of the universe as a whole.
Stars whose brightness changes over time, providing valuable information about their properties and evolution.
The study of objects and phenomena outside of the Milky Way galaxy, such as galaxies, clusters, and supermassive black holes.
The region around a star where conditions may be suitable for life as we know it to exist.
Distinct groups of stars with different ages and compositions, providing insights into galaxy formation and evolution.
Natural sources of microwave emission, similar to lasers but occurring in space, used to study star-forming regions.
discoverer: Gordon H. Pettengill and Frank J. Low

description: A network of pulsars used as precise clocks to detect gravitational waves on cosmic scales.
The region at the center of our Milky Way galaxy, containing a supermassive black hole named Sagittarius A*.
The study of the internal structure of stars by measuring their oscillations and vibrations.
A type of neutron star with an extremely strong magnetic field, capable of producing powerful bursts of X-rays and gamma-rays.
A group of galaxies held together by gravity, ranging from small groups to massive clusters containing thousands of galaxies.
A theory proposing that the universe underwent an extremely rapid expansion in its early moments, solving several cosmological puzzles.
The outer layer of a star where visible light is emitted, providing clues about the star's composition and temperature.
The process by which galaxies evolve and form structures from the early universe to the present.
